awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of gene regulation by the plant MADS-domain transcription factor AGL15 and developmental outcomes.
awd_abstract_narration:
AGL15 is a transcription factor involved in plant embryo development. Transcription factors are proteins that function by binding DNA and turning genes on or off. AGL15 is an example of a 'bimodal' factor that directly expresses some genes, but directly represses other genes, and the focus of this project is to understand how this occurs. Because mechanisms of dual functionality are not well understood in any organism, the proposed work will have broader relevance to understanding these types of factors. Furthermore, AGL15 is involved in seed development, and seeds are of critical importance to humans, with the majority of our diets directly derived from seeds. Additionally, work will contribute to understanding somatic embryogenesis, a step allowing genetic engineering of plants to meet agricultural challenges. Training will be provided for a postdoctoral scholar, a graduate student, and undergraduate researchers, including hosting interns from the nearby community college. This project will support a number of continuing outreach activities as well as developing a new relationship with an elementary school with a high percentage of students from economically disadvantaged homes.

AGL15 is an Arabidopsis MADS-factor involved in developmental phase transitions that directly expresses some genes, but directly represses others. The mechanism of repression may be explained by AGL15's interaction with SAP18/TPL that is part of a histone deacetylase complex (HDAC). This interaction requires an LxLxL/EAR motif that is found within the C-terminal domain of AGL15. The yeast 2-hybrid screen that identified these interactions also isolated proteins that could account for how AGL15 recruitment to gene regulatory elements leads to expression of direct targets. These intriguing proteins, which include another MADS-factor, SEP3, that interacts with chromatin remodeling components and a plant-specific transcription factor (LBD40), will be further investigated, as will the HDAC interaction, and in planta interaction with AGL15 tested. The LxLxL motif, needed for recruitment of the HDAC complex, will be assessed for functional importance in development. Prior NSF support has allowed the PI's lab to map genome wide association of AGL15 with DNA sites and response of target genes. Similar determination of the in vivo association of AGL15 interacting proteins will allow co-occupancy to be determined that may be revealing for mechanism of regulatory outcomes. Some interactors will be assessed for how occupancy changes from embryo to seedling. Prior work on AGL15 has provided clues as to how different complexes with different regulatory outcomes are recruited to specific loci. While mapping association will aid in determining mechanism, experiments are also proposed to directly address the hypothesis that activation may involve multiple binding sites for AGL15 and looping, whereas repression does not. Finally, select targets will be further assessed for epigenetic regulation and function in development. Training at all levels of science are an integral part of the project.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Sharyn Perry’s lab has concluded its work on the project “Mechanisms of gene regulation by the plant MADS-domain transcription factor AGL15 and developmental outcomes” supported by the NSF. The intellectual merit centered on understanding how a protein called AGL15 functions. AGL15 is a protein that controls development by binding to the DNA blueprint of plants and either turns on or off target genes – these types of proteins such as AGL15 are called Transcription Factors (TFs). Significantly, AGL15 can promote a process called somatic embryogenesis in plant tissues when the levels of AGL15 protein are increased. Somatic embryogenesis (SE) is a process by which plant cells can change fate from leaf, root, etc. and instead form a somatic (body) embryo, and subsequently a plantlet. A natural example of SE is in Kalanchoe daigremontiana (common name “Mother-of-thousands”) where cells at the leaf margins generate SE that become new plantlets. However, in most cases, this form of plant regeneration requires much effort and does not work for many plant species or particular agronomically important cultivars. SE is important for plant regeneration for a variety of basic and applied science studies. For applied work, any genetic engineering to modify genomes for added value of plants (e.g. virus-resistant papaya is a famous example) requires regeneration of the modified plant cell. It is also a means to rapidly propagate valuable types of some plants that normally require decades to reach reproductive stage (e.g. trees). Basic science often involves changing how a particular DNA sequence of interest functions by increasing or decreasing function and looking at the result. This also involves the need to regenerate plants after altering the function of the DNA.

The goal of the work was to better understand how AGL15 promotes SE. AGL15 can both turn on or off genes and is thus considered a dual function TF. The work supported by this award allowed the lab to determine parts of AGL15 needed for this dual function and the effects on SE. Surprisingly, a region that in other proteins is involved in turning off gene expression was important in AGL15 for this function for some genes but not others. One means by which dual-function TFs work is by forming complexes with other proteins. A number of such interactions for AGL15 were identified, verified, and genes regulated by these interactions identified.  The work resulted in seven publications in peer reviewed scientific journals to date, with an additional manuscript in review. Several datasets were deposited in public repositories to aid other researchers’ efforts. Two Ph.D. students were trained who defended their dissertations during the award period – both are currently continuing work in plant molecular science as postdoctoral scholars. One postdoc was trained who now works with a local biotechnology company. The senior lab technician also benefited from the support in terms of co-authorship on a paper. Twelve undergraduate researchers were trained in the lab varying from gaining their first lab experience to performing their independent research projects for their B.S. degrees. Those whom Perry has tracked (ten) are still pursuing their undergraduate or higher degrees, or are working in science/technical fields. Two of these were international visiting students. Finally, one high school student from a program for underrepresented minorities in Science was hosted for 2.5 years. He made tremendous progress in terms of presentation skills (from could not talk in front of a group to winning first place in the Science fair) and served as a co-author on a paper published during this award period. In terms of building infrastructure at UK, Perry led several successful requests to the department to obtain shared pieces of equipment totaling ~$28,000. Competiveness for these types of funds is positively influenced by external funding. 


Last Modified: 09/12/2023
Modified by: Sharyn E Perry
